name: State_5 (coastal)

timeline_beats.label: Initial coastal settlement and reef-harbor founding
Integration into regional river-coast trade networks
Great Naval War; major fleet actions off state shores
Territorial shifts and port reorganization after naval conflict
Entry into maritime accords and trade bloc membership

factions.label: Harbor Merchants Guild
factions.influence_hint: dominant economic / controls customs and long-distance trade contracts

factions.label: Tide-Templars
factions.influence_hint: religious order; controls ritual auguries for navigation and coastal rites

factions.label: Shipwrights & Chandlers Combine
factions.influence_hint: industrial; controls shipbuilding yards and reagent-linked workshops

factions.label: Estuary Shadow Network
factions.influence_hint: informal smugglers and brokers; influence in border/black-market trade

traits: commercial pragmatism with formal hospitality codes

external_relations_refs.label_hint: Territorial Shifts after Great Naval War

constraints: No instant resurrection or true life-replacement magics
Long-range mind influence is rare and institutionally banned
Navigational auguries cannot replace charts or seamanship
Combustion-derived industry limited; no high-pressure steam megatechs
Ritual magic consumes scarce imported reagents or specialized labor
Must comply with Open-Seas Treaty (T1) obligations and post-war border settlements (BC4)
notes: High dependence on imported reagents and maritime trade routes for ritual and industry
Factional tensions: Harbor Merchants vs. Tide-Templars over control of auguries and port policy
Coastal exposure makes naval capability and alliance membership (A1/TB1) strategically critical
Smuggling networks exploit post-war border reorganization (BC4); enforcement uneven
